byline.original: By STEPHEN CASTLE and JACK EWING
byline.contributor: Stephen Castle reported from Brussels, and Jack Ewing from Frankfurt. Liz Alderman contributed reporting from Paris, and Elisabetta Povoledo from Rome.

abstract: European officials scramble to find a way to entice banks to accept much deeper losses on their Greek bonds as debt crisis talks reach crucial point; banks have taken a hard line and have warned that the write-off of debts they are being asked to agree to, which could be as much as 55 percent, could result in a default, prompting a search by officials for so-called complimentary measures to sweeten the deal.
snippet: A day before a crucial meeting of European leaders, officials were trying to persuade banks to accept much deeper losses on their holdings of Greek debt.
lead_paragraph: A day before a crucial meeting of European leaders, officials were trying to persuade banks to accept much deeper losses on their holdings of Greek debt.

headline.main: Banks Face Pressure on Eve of Meeting on Debt Crisis
headline.print_headline: Banks Face Pressure on Eve Of Meeting on Debt Crisis
headline.seo: Banks Under Pressure on Eve of Debt Meeting
